Abigail, which was considered a failure by most, released on streaming on May 7th, released in theaters on April 19th. idea was to build buzz and  word of mouth It was actually the Godfather that was one of the first movies to open in hundreds and hundreds of  theaters at the same time to massive success so Jaws did rights documentary or a history textbook you had in high school you might not notice this guy as anything stand out at least on appearance compared to other American politicians but his career is bizarre his early life is about as bland as you might expect he gets some law degrees he serves in the military he fights in World War 2 and then he decides he's going to launch into politics in his home state my home state of Alabama and he's gonna run for his first attempt democratic primary as a moderate integration is really becoming a conversation that the that the country is having particularly the federal government is having by the 1950s and Wallace wants to take a middle of the road position on this now understand middle of the road for Southern Democrats in the 50s is like very far right for what we would consider today Wallace is going to lose he's going to lose his initial primary against his opponent who was endorsed by the KKK that tells you where the white south was in the 1950s and from that point forward Wallace jettisons any notion of being a moderate on issues of integration Wallace rebrands his public image after his defeat in the primary to be a fire breathing segregationist and this has LED to some really genuine I think critique that Wallace never really believed in anything Wallace believed in advancing Wallace's political goals and so when moderate didn't work he switched to fire breather and that fire breather position is going to win him the governorship where his single focus is populist economics for white folks and segregation those are his like only two things and he's entering political life in an age where the Democratic Party is really realigning that you have Northern Democrats that are weirdly centered around Lyndon Johnson who is himself a former Southern Democrat but has now moved to more Liberal positions on a range of issues and the Southern Democrats themselves the Dixiecrats who seem to be sort of pigeon holding into only segregation is all they have Wallace's next major sort of move forward in politics is when he loses the ability to be governor in Alabama he can't run again he's term limited Laura Lean Wallace his wife moves into the governorship she's going to run for governor with Wallace as a sort of puppet master of her campaign worthy of note Laura Lean is actively dying of cancer the voice_to_text: how are we supposed to interpret this portrait of King Charles so Buckingham Palace just released the latest official portrait of King Charles it was made by a painter called Jonathan Yeo he's a very successful portraitist and already the internet has a lot of opinions about this painting about what it represents so let's break it down visually one of the first things you notice about this painting is the color  royal portraits tend to be pretty subdued this colour this bright pink orangey red is far from subdued Yeo and the palace described it as “vibrant” but as many people online have pointed out it looks like Charles is engulfed in flames or blood The flame thing I think they're getting from the very frenetic nature of the brush strokes right you can really see their texture and that's creating a heat and almost iridescence that we might associate with flames and the texture on his suit makes it almost look like his uniform is melting The red undertones are hard not to associate with the blood like color which again as people pointed out it's easy to interpret that as the blood of the British Empire's colonialism Yeo mentioned that he included the butterfly because it's a symbol of change and renewal and rebirth a nod to Charles's climate activism it looks especially fragile and endangered in this environment to me the most striking thing is his head it's a totally different color palette it looks like it's floating when I think of floating heads and Kings and Queens I think of beheading and revolution I would be so curious to hear what you think of the painting I think there's a lot of room for interpretation I don't think it's particularly flattering

video_description: A Vader movie is a win win for everyone #vader #darthvader #starwars #starwarsfan #starwarstiktok
voice_to_text: I'm absolutely baffled by the fact that we still haven't gotten a Darth Vader movie. I mean, come on, he's arguably the most iconic villain of all time. There's so much potential there. It's practically begging to be made. Imagine the box office numbers if they announced a standalone Vader movie. Especially if they brought back Hayden Christensen to reprise the role. It would be an absolute gold mine. And yet here we are, still waiting. For all the people who argue that the original six movies are about Vader, they couldn't be more wrong. The prequels are about Anakin Skywalker's journey to becoming Vader, and the originals are about Luke's struggle against him. But despite being the central figure of the saga, Vader screen time across all six movies is less than 40 minutes. A dedicated Vader movie would finally give him the spotlight he deserves, delving deep into his emotional struggles and conflicts, especially in the aftermath of revenge of the Sith. But what do you guys think? Would you want Disney to make a Vader movie, or should they keep making same content they've been doing?

Text DONATE to 43428 to help Earthjustice protect wildlife from seismic air gun suveys. #seismic #whale #dolphins #ecotok #oilandgas #climatechange
voice_to_text: The oil and gas industry is profiting by setting off explosions in one of the world's biological hotspots. This is called seismic airgun surveying, and it's used to search the ocean for oil. A single ship can blast every 10 seconds, 24 hours a day, seven days a week, for months on end. The air guns are like mini cannons and the blast can exceed 235 decibels, which is hundreds of times more intense than a jet engine. A marine mammal in the vicinity would be deafened. Most of this is happening in the Gulf of Mexico, home to some of the world's most endangered species. The blasts can inflict permanent, even fatal, hearing damage on whales, dolphins, even affect the plankton that's the foundation of the ocean food web. The sound waves can be heard across the entire Gulf. This near constant level of noise can mask vital calls that marine mammals depend on to survive. The Biden administration has a chance to reign in this harmful activity. Unfortunately, it issued a new rule that would still allow extensive seismic testing in the Gulf of Mexico. The environmental law organization Earthjustice is asking the administration to change course and correct the rule, so that it protects Gulf wildlife from seismic air gun surveys. If you'd like to support this work please text DONATE to 43438

some comments from people saying that some movies that I had mentioned just aren't rewatchable which I think is so funny so what makes a movie rewatchable funny enough I think this is actually like maybe even more subjective than is the movie good or bad it comes down to not just do you think this movie is good do you think this movie is bad it's do you actually find yourself wanting to rewatch this movie and that's a whole different question so for me I think the first thing that when it comes to rewatchability the first thing for me is enjoyability doesn't have to be good doesn't have to be bad but do I enjoy watching this movie there are some movies that I enjoy watching that are objectively not very good uh Troll 2 is a good example of a movie that I think is very rewatchable but is not a good movie it's very fun to watch that movie especially with a group of friends short people who've never seen it before but it's not good it's not a good movie yet I find it so rewatchable I also find that movies that make me feel good are movies that I tend to rewatch not every movie I rewatch makes me feel good but something like big Trouble little China for me is a movie that makes me feel good Star Wars is a movie that makes me feel good once upon a time in Hollywood is my most rewatched movie over the past couple of years and it's because I just enjoy being in that world I enjoy the music I enjoy the characters I enjoy kind of hanging out with them in this movie I love this movie it's my favorite movie and then there's the experience of certain movies movies like Vertigo or even the Exorcist to me those are experiences I watch them and I'm dazzled by what I'm seeing on screen and the artistry on display from Hitchcock or Friedkin and I find myself gravitating to those movies and wanting to kind of experience the artistry of film in movies like that and also I find myself gravitating to movies that are difficult or have themes or underlying symbolism that I want to work through so when it comes down to is a movie rewatchable or not I think that is a question you need to ask yourself a movie that is rewatchable for you may be something I have no interest in rewatching my wife grew up watching Mulan Rouge constantly one of the most rewatched movies in her house you couldn't pay me to watch Mulan Rouge more than twice so it's all subjective cause that's what this is this is all film is just it's just a bunch of subjective stuff and we have fun with it and we love it and that's why we talk about it I'm so interested in this question now that I've made two videos about it so tell me what are your most rewatched movies and why are you drawn to rewatching those movies let me know

voice_to_text: Me. Something a job has taught you that you will never, ever forget, no matter what. That they don't care. They don't care that you got in a wreck on the way to work. They don't care that your babysitter didn't show up. They don't care that you just bought a house. This is coming from someone who sat on the executive board, with the CEO, with the C O O, with all of the higher UPS. They don't care. They don't care what you have going outside of work. It is about the result. It is about the deliverable. And the sooner you remove the emotion out of the work that you do, the further that you can go. Because when you start to think that they care if you had a bad day, then you give yourself an excuse to have a bad day. When you think that they hear that you're doing really well in your personal life, you give yourself an excuse. When you remove the emotion, you will go further. Show up, be passionate about the work that you were doing. If you are. If you don't care about the work you're doing, do the bare minimum, but take the emotion out of it. And stop people thinking that people care. It wasn't until I understood this that I doubled my salary and was able to get promoted. It sounds cold, but it's true.

video_description: Animated movies and shows keep getting mediocre live action adaptations. same universe, different story is *chefs kiss* #animation #movies #avatarthelastairbender
voice_to_text: Are live action adaptations of shows ever a good thing? Take a look at all these live action movies slash shows adapted from animation. How many of them make you say I would rather watch the live action adaptation than the animated original? For me, Scooby Doo movies, maybe Ruroni Kenshin, and that's it. I don't give a crap about the rest. Compared to their animated counterparts, some of these are downright bad. And the good ones usually aren't better than the original animated show or movie. So why even bother with live action in the first place? Stupid reasons. For starters. 1. People like making money. We already know that most of Hollywood would rather produce a spin on an already beloved IP than create anything truly new. The latter is too much of a risk. God forbid you take risks in art. Art is about profit for shareholders. Second, I think some people view animation as a lesser medium for kids or adults that never grew out of their childlike interest, and that turning animation into live action can make it blockbuster worthy. Also, while I don't think that live action adaptations are made with Oscars in mind, I think it's interesting that over the span of 96 years, only three animated films have been nominated for Best Picture. Animation isn't always given the same respect that live action is. I can, however, think of two good reasons to adapt animation into live action. First, to open up The story to a wider audience, kind of catering to people that have the perspective I just mentioned. As much as I love animation, I know there's people that don't care to watch animated shows, but would probably love the story if it was presented to them in live action. Honestly though, I'm in favor of just encouraging more people to watch animated shows and movies. Second to tell a brand new story that takes place in the animated original universe. An example of this would be Scooby Doo. One of the potential reasons that the Scooby Doo movies were enjoyable is because they were written for live action. They didn't try to one to one recreate the most popular episodes of the animated show. However, I think there's some aspects of animated shows that are really hard to adapt to live action, like certain visual goofs, character designs, and the overall vibe, for lack of better words. Like a live action Adventure Time, no matter how good their CGI budget is, probably won't feel like Adventure Time. I think it's important when adapting from animation to live action to consider the differences and strengths of each medium and really think how could this story or these characters benefit from or be expanded upon in a live action setting? Because a one to one recreation of animation more often than not falls flat.

video_description: The best culinary experience I’ve ever had— dining at Iris in Rosendal, Norway inside of the Salmon Eye. A 6 hour long, 18 course “expedition dining” experience, it’s not for the faint of heart— but if you’re someone who loves food and adventure, this is something you need to add to your bucket list! #irisrestaurant #salmoneye #expeditiondining #themenu #fyp
voice_to_text: Have you heard of expedition dining? This is Restaurant Iris, located inside of a floating art installation called The Salmon Eye, nestled within the breathtaking Norwegian fjords. To get there, you take an electric boat with fellow Extreme Foodies, which first stops at the Chef's Boathouse, where you served a couple of amazing bites and a glass of local cider. Then after another short ride, it's time for the main event, dining inside of the Salmon Eye. The entire experience is a journey beginning under the water surface, literally complete with a thematic seaweed crisp that you collect yourself, and a dreamy sea urchin moose, their version of chips and dip, to welcome you into their space. You then move upstairs and into the lounge for a few more incredible bites. Next, more amazing dishes take center stage at a table with breathtaking views. Each dish had a story inspired by the surrounding nature, from the mountains to the ocean, and all the ingredients are sourced as locally as possible. Then it's time to wind down back in the lounge with tea, coffee and chocolates before heading back to reality. Goodbye, Iris. Until next time.

voice_to_text: Have you ever asked yourself, why didn't Elrond just dropkick Isildur into Mount Doom when he refused to destroy the One Ring? It would have solved everything. Welcome to the Fantasy Annexe. There's an argument to be made that no one fully understood how crucial it was to destroy the ring. But I think that's debatable. There are more impactful reasons for Elrond's actions. For one, by the time Sauron is defeated, the elves and humans had been fighting in the War of the Last Alliance against him for over 10 years. I think it's very fair to assume that Elrond and Isildur are close by the end of this war. On top of that, Isildur is Elrond's nephew, a few generations removed. You gonna ask him to take out a family member like that? If you're ignoring their relationship, consider the politics. Elrond and Isildur are the highest ranking members of the elven and human armies, respectively. If word got out that Elrond killed Isildur, the political ramifications would be devastating. It may have even started a second war, this time between elves and humans. If none of those reasons are good enough, then I ask you this. At the end of Return of the King, Frodo and Sam find themselves in a similar situation when Frodo refuses to destroy the ring. Do we legitimately think Sam would have or should have pushed Frodo into Mount Doom? Just because we didn't see Elrond and Isildur’s story and struggle doesn't mean that we can expect Elrond to have done any different than Sam. Follow for more fantasy content.
